_data.description: The main concept we revolve around here is delivering data from the server to the client whenever some data is changed in the server using short polling & long polling & server-sent events `SSE` & web-sockets.
_data.title: Developing Real Time Applications | Part 1

children.value: Actually, the main purpose of starting this series is to improve my English writing skills. also for the last 6 months, I had many tasks in my work that required me to deal with real-time applications like building a simple chat, showing real-time statistics/notifications in a dashboard...etc.

So in this series, I'll try to cover some ideas, approaches, technologies, and code examples around this concept. I don't have much experience so there are no headlines. I will just start the journey and let's find out together how much this series could grow.
will be so glad for your help in fixing a typo, introducing a better way to construct a phrase, or giving me some feedback about my English writing.
Now, I'm writing this post while enjoying listening to this calm and peaceful

The main concept we revolve around here is delivering data from the server to the client whenever some data is changed in the server. we have 2 approaches to achieve that, client pull and server push.
When the client is asking the server for data, this is called
The reverse, when the transmission of data is initiated by the server, this is called
To implement these 2 approaches we have some techniques:
In this part, we will try to cover these 4 techniques.
In this technique, the client constantly asking the server for new data. we can think about it like this conversation between the client & server:
Server: yes, the restaurant is preparing your food
Server: yes, your food is in-delivery now
It's obvious that this technique wastes the server resources.
HTTP headers for each incoming request must be parsed.
a response must be generated and delivered to the client.
this process will keep running multiple times for every client. so it's a bad practice for something like chat application.

However, The previous conversation could be a good example of using this technique. think about it! after a regular user orders his meal from an ordering food app, a page should appear to him indicating the status of his order like:
On this page, usually no user spends 35 min watching the status of his order. of course he may keep the page opened but it's ok for some

- the different time between changing the order status value in the server and showing it in the page - unlike chat messaging for example. so Instead of thinking of a complicated solution we can use the Short Polling technique and make the period between requests is 30 seconds or so.
Now we will write a very simple example of this technique. let's run this script on the server-side.

/**
 * this is a mock to a function which perform a query and do some
 * calculations to get the top seller today
 * 
 *
we can run this script using the command below:
and for the client we can write this script.
<!-- VUE will show us the fetched top seller here -->
// here we start to fetch the top seller for the first time
// here we will fetch the top seller again after 3 seconds
function in the success part of the
and here is how the request keeps going to
every 3 seconds. now the data seem to be real-time.
We can think of this technique as a fork of
. remember the previous conversation between the client & server? this technique will try to eliminate the empty responses
and also reduce the delay time.

The server holds the client's connection and waits for some information to be available. once the information becomes available (or after the request timeout) a response will be returned to the client.
We will make some modifications to the previous example of the
technique. first, let's start with the code in the server.
Here the server is expecting the client's
value. and will hold the connection until the
value will differ from the client value. notice how the server is calling
function each second as long as the client & server values are the same.
Now let's figure out how could we modify the client code. here we are only interested in the
// --- fetch the top seller again in case (success|request-timeout)
immediately after getting the response from the server. no
anymore. of course this may differ depending on your app.
This is the chrome's network tap, and you can see how the last request is pending. it's obvious that at this moment the client's
value equals to the server value which is
. and now the server is holding the connection by using
method until its value differs from the client value.
I really liked this technique the first time I implemented it.
, this diagram will help us to remember the difference between short and long polling.
This technique is very interesting although it's not popular. we still using the traditional HTTP.

Firstly the client sends a single request to the server. after that, the server can keep pushing data (sending events) to the client. on the other hand, the client needs to handle the received data (listening to server events).
Note that the client canâ€™t send messages to the server, only receiving data.
We will continue modifying our example in the previous techniques. let's start with the code on the server.
Notice how the server responds with the header
so the client will be prepared for listening to the incoming events.
Also, notice that each notification/event the server send is consists of 2 lines (could be more);
event: this is the event name and we can listen to it from the browser.
Now let's figure out how could we modify the client code. here we are also only interested in the
We are listening to the event
which we just sent from the server. then we show our top seller. so simple, right?
Note that, If the connection drops, the
fires an error event and automatically tries to reconnect.
looks like in Chrome's network tab. notice inside the
which is the event that we are listening to.
Before moving forward to web-socket you need to know that
. and also the maximum number of the opened connections for a single domain in the browser - for all tabs - is 6.
At some point in the history of the Internet, some organizations showed up called
'Standards Development Organizations'. You likely heard about some of them like
We might say the main role of these organizations is to describe in a very detailed and formal way some aspects/technologies of the world wide web.
Some examples of the documents/specifications produced by
Hypertext Markup Language (HTML) the 5th major revision

Usually, the documents developed by these organizations are not very useful for learning how to use the technologies they describe, however they are intended to be used by software engineers to implement these technologies.
. In this section, we will try to understand the main idea this document is introducing.
and depends on TCP protocol at layer 4 -
Whenever a computer wants to send data to another computer over TCP, they both need to make 3 steps:
one computer sends packets of data and the recipient computer acknowledges what he received.
Now imagine we have a server that serves a client chat application which is built using the

technique. If we have 1 client communicating with the server then each HTTP request is considered as a different TCP connection. And If we have multiple clients then the server needs to handle multiple TCP connections for every single client. of course this is high overhead.
What web-socket protocol is introduced is to use only a single TCP connection for every single client. and data can be sent in both directions between the client & server.
a client sends a traditional HTTP request with some specific headers like
if the server supports the WebSocket Protocol, it will replay with some headers and completes the handshake.
: if the handshake is successful, (the client & server have agreed to use the existing TCP connection as a WebSocket connection), each side can send
This diagram will help us to remember the difference between the traditional HTTP and Websocket Protocol:
This is enough for now and in the future, we will dive deeper into this technique and write some code.

We talked about different approaches and techniques. but at the end of this part, we need to remember that there is no an old bad technique & a new good one. you know the software you are building and you have to pick the suitable solution for your situation.
In the next parts, we may talk about some concepts like:
see you in the next part in-sha-Allah. salam.
